item.title: What if a single grain of sand hit Earth at light speed?
item.description: Imagine the energy of a single speck traveling at the speed of light. This experiment breaks down the physics behind extreme collisions, revealing just how powerful even the tiniest object can be in theory.

media:content.media:title: What if a single grain of sand hit Earth at light speed?
media:content.media:description: Imagine the energy of a single speck traveling at the speed of light. This experiment breaks down the physics behind extreme collisions, revealing just how powerful even the tiniest object can be in theory.

item.title: Making light come out of my eyes!
item.description: The illusion of glowing eyes. It’s not superpowers, it’s pure science and precision lighting at work!

item.title: Why do grains defy gravity?
item.description: In this experiment, we explore the strange behavior of granular materials, how tiny grains can appear to defy gravity, flow like fluids, and even climb walls under vibration. Physics gets surprisingly weird at small scales!

item.title: Can you make a computer out of gears and chains?
item.description: This experiment explores whether gears and chains can really perform logic, revealing the fascinating link between motion, math, and machinery.

item.title: Coins flapping like butterflies
item.description: Discover how simple motion can make coins flutter and flap as if they were alive, a mesmerizing display of resonance in action.

item.title: Trapping an electron in a box
item.description: What happens when you confine a single electron to an impossibly tiny space? This experiment explores quantum confinement and the strange behavior of particles that follow the rules of probability, not logic.

item.title: A tube made out of liquid
item.description: Discover how physics allows liquids to form stable structures that seem to defy gravity.

item.title: Why pulleys are weirder than you think?
item.description: Exploring pulleys and their surprising behaviors, uncovering the physics behind everyday simple machines.

item.title: Spinning a top within a top
item.description: Showing how a smaller top can spin inside a larger one, revealing surprising insights into rotation and stability.

item.title: The science behind a digital sundial
item.description: Exploring how a digital sundial uses light and shadows to tell the time

item.title: Neverwet on water...?
item.description: Testing the superhydrophobic coating Neverwet on water to see how it repels liquids and creates unexpected effects.

item.title: When 3D isn’t enough
item.description: Exploring experiments that go beyond traditional 3D visuals, showing how depth and perception can be pushed in surprising ways.

item.title: Can light be black?
item.description: A fascinating experiment examining whether light can appear black and how materials interact with it

item.title: The dark truth about chips
item.description: This eye opening experiment reveals the dark truth about potato chips

item.title: Can a superconductor defy gravity?
item.description: Watch this mind-bending experiment as a superconductor levitates effortlessly, floating in mid-air like magic but it’s pure physics!

item.title: Perfect Oreo separation
item.description: This experiment tests different techniques to separate Oreo cookies without breaking the cream.

item.title: The forever pen
item.description: Discover the Forever Pen, a compact, inkless writing tool that uses a silver alloy tip to leave permanent marks on various surfaces

item.title: Stretch Armstrong vs. Vacuum chamber
item.description: Watch what happens when a Stretch Armstrong toy is placed in a vacuum chamber. See how it stretches, inflates, and reacts to the pressure changes in real time.

item.title: Photosynthesis in real time
item.description: Observe how plants convert light into energy in real time—this experiment captures gas exchange, color change, and growth as photosynthesis unfolds before your eyes.

item.title: Sending the internet through water
item.description: Exploring whether data signals can be transmitted through water using light or lasers, testing the limits of underwater internet tech.
